title: SRD approves 30% tax hike for Area C, 4% tax bump for other electoral districts
bodyText:
Area C is set to pay the steepest property tax hike of all the electoral areas in the Strathcona Regional District as part of its recently approved financial plan.

Homeowners in the Discovery Islands and Mainland Inlets will see an average increase of 30 per cent, or $193 per home in 2025. This jump is attributed to a shift in how funds are distributed within the electoral area and enhancements to the community hall services, library services, and 9-1-1 response levels, explained Mike Harmston, chief financial officer with the SRD.

The shift in the allocation policy has led to higher taxes, Harmston said, but it also brings advantages through various services that come with user fees.

"Area C has the highest tax increase, but they also get the highest benefit from user fees with a change of allocations," he said.

Harmston added that when looking at comparable regions, such as Denman Island and Hornby islands, the tax increase is "well below average."

Area A will see a four per cent increase, which translates to an additional $30 for the average homeowner, resulting from the change in the overhead allocation policy and increased costs associated with funding the Vancouver Island Regional Library. A regional partnership between the Village of Sayward and Electoral Area A will improve cost-sharing and operational efficiency in the Fire Service, according to a SRD media release from April 1.

A four per cent increase of $64 per average home is expected for Area B, mainly due to the change in the overhead allocation policy and increased costs associated with funding the Vancouver Island Regional Library, says the release.

Area D will see a four per cent increase of $96 per average home, primarily due to increased funding for recreation, enhanced transit, and library service levels, notes the release.

The rises in the average household expenses are partly due in part to a new overhead allocation policy that aims to more fairly spread the general administrative costs across all regional district participants, notes the release.

The SRD said the 2025-2029 Financial Plan reinforces its commitment to strategic investment, sound financial management, and advancing the board's priorities in community well-being, climate resilience, and good governance.

"The financial plan serves as a guiding framework for the regional district's operations and strategic initiatives, ensuring the delivery of essential services while preparing for future growth and sustainability," reads the release.

Despite inflationary pressures and rising operational costs, the SRD said it remains dedicated to responsible growth and enhancing its communities.

The plan includes key investments in disaster risk reduction and climate adaptation, with senior government grants that will fund projects focused on

wildfire preparedness, climate adaptation, and environmental responsibility.

"Significant work has gone into ensuring this plan meets the needs of our residents while focusing on long-term sustainability and regional prosperity," said SRD chair Mark Baker in the release. "Our investments in recreation, housing, environmental resilience, and governance will benefit the region for generations to come."

For more details on the Strathcona Regional District's financial planning process or to view the approved budget, visit www.srd.ca/financial-planning.

title: Hope gets $150,000 for disaster-risk reduction project
bodyText:
The District of Hope will be reducing the community’s risk for climate-based disasters, thanks to a $150,000 grant from the provincial government.

Hope is one of 39 communities who are collectively receiving more than $19 million, from the Ministry of Emergency Management and Climate Readiness (MOEMCR), to fund projects to “strengthen their defences against the effects of climate change.”

A total of 46 projects are being funded and Hope will be using the money to improve hazard identification and risk mapping for the community.

The funding comes from the Community Emergency Preparedness Fund (CEPF), through the Disaster Risk Reduction-Climate Adaptation (DRRCA) stream.

“B.C. is on the front lines of climate change, and investing in disaster-risk reduction and climate adaptation has never been more critical,” said Kelly Greene, the Minister of MOEMCR, in a press release on Jan. 30. “We are taking action to build stronger, safer communities that are better prepared to protect people for generations to come.”

Due to the 2021 November floods, and the influx of the wildfires over the past few years (such as the Kookipi Creek wildfire, and Flood Falls Trail wildfire), the district has been increasing their efforts to fortify Hope. This includes working to improve the community’s storm drainage system, clearing berms, improving dike stability, and more recently hiring a FireSmart coordinator to help create a community wildfire resiliency plan.
